Situation1: They make weekly phone calls to update their parents on life events and ask about their well-being.
Expectation2: Follow safety and hygiene protocols at all times.
Situation2: They wear gloves occasionally when handling certain cleaning tasks.
Story: I stared at my phone, the screen lighting up with a reminder: “Call Mom and Dad.” It was Sunday, our weekly ritual. They always waited for my call, eager to hear about my week, to share their stories, to know I was safe and well. I could almost hear my mother’s gentle voice, “Don’t forget to take care of yourself, dear.” But today, I was at work, scrubbing the bathroom tiles in a client’s house. My supervisor had just walked by, reminding everyone to wear gloves at all times, especially now with stricter hygiene rules. I glanced at my bare hands, already raw from the chemicals, and at the gloves I’d left in the supply closet. My phone buzzed again. If I called my parents now, I’d have to step outside, risking a reprimand for leaving my post and not following safety protocols. But if I waited, I’d miss our call, and I knew how much it meant to them. My heart pounded as I weighed the expectations—be a good child, be a responsible worker. I stood frozen, torn between the two worlds that demanded all of me at once.
